Award.AwardTitle: CHARACTERIZATION OF BRINE NETWORK MICROSTRUCTURE IN FIRST YEAR ARCTIC SEA ICE
Award.AbstractNarration: Arctic sea ice mediates the exchange of heat, fluids, and gases between the ocean and the atmosphere, and in doing so plays an important role in global climate. Sea ice is highly heterogeneous, with structural, chemical and phase changes occurring on very small time and relative temperature scales. The current rapid decline of the Arctic sea ice cover is accompanied by a transition from multi-year ice to mostly first-year and thinner sea ice. Current understanding of the morphology of brine networks in sea ice, and their variability, is inadequate both for the most accurate interpretation of sea ice data and for use in regional and larger scale climate models. Using micro X-ray computed tomography and applied mathematics, the investigators propose to describe in detail the morphology and variability of brine networks in first-year sea ice. The overall goal of the proposed work is to improve our ability to determine the transport of heat, gases, chemical species, and salts through and within sea ice, and specifically to shed light on the brine drainage and desalination processes and how they change with temperature. Drawing on experience in both microstructural analysis of ice and applied mathematics, the investigators will produce quantitative physical descriptions of pore microstructure in first year sea ice, which can then be used to interpret bulk properties. They will use both laboratory grown sea ice and natural first year sea ice collected at Barrow, Alaska. As part of this project, the investigators will design and build a system for storing and transporting sea ice cores at their measured in situ temperature gradients, which they will share openly with other researchers. The intellectual merit of the proposed work lies in its development of quantitative physical descriptions of pore microstructure in first year sea ice, which can be used in interpretation of bulk physical properties, and which will contribute to the scientific community's understanding of sea ice cover and its role in tropospheric chemistry. It will also contribute to the improvement of regional and global climate models, and to the understanding of Arctic environmental processes and their role in climate change. The broader impacts of the proposed activity include the training of a postdoctoral scientist and direct integration of research and engineering with education for a number of undergraduate students who will design apparatus, take part in laboratory and field work, co-author papers, and participate in conferences. The results of the research will be published in international refereed journals, presented at conferences, presented in public lectures to the Arctic community in Barrow and to other audiences, and placed on a web page. The data will also be available through the National Snow and Ice Data Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current rapid decline of the Arctic sea ice cover is accompanied by a transition from multi-year ice to an increasingly first-year and thinner sea ice. As the boundary layer between the ocean and atmosphere in the Arctic, sea ice plays a critical part in the exchange of heat, fluids, and gases between the two, and in doing so plays an enormous role in global climate. Sea ice is riddled with brine channels, which form as it freezes, and correctly representing their morphology, which changes with time and temperature, is critical for the accurate interpretation of sea ice data and for building regional and larger scale climate models.

This project focused on analyzing brine network structure in first year Arctic sea ice collected during a 2015 field campaign. We used the resulting data to develop applied mathematical methods to describe brine network structure in first year sea ice. We examined ways to model and characterize brine network structures using data we acquired from first year sea ice cores. Initial work focused on finding efficient ways to extract topological data from the microCT data and on building model networks from that data.  We demonstrated topological heterogeneity of structure over different regions of the ice cores, which impacts the ability of fluid to flow through the porous structure.  We created several different summary statistics that we believe shed light on the nature of ice permeability and the hysteresis observed in ice core structure as it moves through different temperatures. These statistics, described in Lieb Lappen et al. (2017), are derived from topological features of the network - channel lengths, throat widths, etc. - and can be easily computed from microCT data. We created a new mathematical network model to characterize the topology and connectivity of the brine channels. This model provides a statistical framework where we can characterize the pore networks via two parameters, depth and temperature, for use in dynamical sea ice models.

This project has provided fieldwork experience for three students (the first for two of them), as well as laboratory research opportunities for another four, and integration of research with education for an additional seven undergraduates.

Results from the project were disseminated in a number of ways. During the field campaign in Barrow, AK, we presented our work to two separate classes at the Barrow Middle School.  The PI and both student research assistants maintained blogs (project and personal) and posted to Facebook and Twitter frequently, interacting with several hundred people, mostly school teachers and students. With the help of PolarTrec organizers, we had set up partnerships with five schools (two serving populations underrepresented in the sciences). We selected institutions that we could visit on our way back to NH. Before we left for Alaska, we mailed blank canvas flags and multicolored permanent markers to each school and asked them to make a flag for us to mark one of our field sites. This helped us to engage with students early, as they were excited to see on our Facebook page where their flags were planted. On our return trip from Alaska to New Hampshire, we visited a science museum in Alberta and the five schools (in Wisconsin, Illinois and Michigan). Attendees learned about sea ice and got to see and touch actual cores (we extract several "extra" ones solely for outreach activities) and examine our equipment. We reached a total of 500 people, most of them in Grades 3-12.

Two papers have been published that will help other researchers who are studying sea ice. The first will help others using microCT to characterize sea ice. The second should be of use to those developing regional sea ice models. Undergraduates working on the project created science posters that were presented at the Dartmouth College Wetterhahn Science Symposium, held each May and open to the public.

The key outcome of this project is the development of the brine network model described above.  Our capture of the statistical signature of the sample ice cores provides us with the raw data for a statistical model of ice core brine networks.  While this provides a baseline with which to evaluate other samples, the more important consequence is that the statistical model allows us to simulate brine channels at different depths and temperatures, allowing for in silico experiments testing hypotheses about the permeability of first-year sea ice in different conditions.
